title: 109_hr4446
content: The Act may be cited as the "Legislative Branch Officer Appointment Act of 2005". It pertains to the Architect of the Capitol. The Architect of the Capitol is appointed jointly by congressional leaders for a 10-year term, with the possibility of reappointment. A section of the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act is repealed, and there is a limit on the total annual compensation. The compensation of the Architect of the Capitol is amended to be equal to the higher salary of the House of Representatives or Senate Sergeant at Arms, with a total annual compensation limit not exceeding a Member of Congress's pay. This amendment applies to compensation starting from the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 3. COMPTROLLER GENERAL. The Comptroller General's appointment process and term of service have been revised, with a joint appointment by key Congressional leaders and a reduced term of 10 years. Additionally, there is now a limit on the total annual compensation amount. The annual rate of compensation for the Comptroller General is capped at the annual rate of pay for a Member of Congress. The amendment also repeals Section 772 of title 31, United States Code. Effective immediately for compensation paid after the enactment of this Act. Repeal of Section 772 of title 31, United States Code, with corresponding amendments to Title 31. The Librarian of Congress is appointed jointly by congressional leaders, serves a 10-year term, and can be reappointed. The Librarian establishes rules for the Library of Congress. The Supplemental Appropriations Act, 1983 is amended to limit the total annual amount of compensation paid. The Librarian of Congress's compensation, including salary and other payments, cannot exceed the annual rate of pay for a Member of Congress. This amendment applies to compensation paid after the enactment of the Act.
